Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Evolutionary complexity and diversity of chemical defenses in diurnal and nocturnal fireflies
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will provide insight into the origin and maintenance of complex chemical diversity associated with alternative ecological strategies. Antipredator defenses often consist of multiple parts functioning as a single unit. Two key questions are: (1) What factors favor particular defensive traits? (2) How are these strategies integrated into the phenotype? Chemical defenses in fireflies provide an excellent system for evaluating these questions. Fireflies are primarily known for bioluminescent flashing, but most also make diverse blends of toxins that vary in chemical structure and concentration. Yet, little is known about firefly chemical diversity, and how it-and complex traits in general-evolve. For example, are shifts between diurnal and nocturnal activity (and associated loss or gain of bioluminescence) accompanied by changes in chemical defense evolution? This research will quantify the diversity of chemical defenses across the firefly phylogeny and use comparative methods to estimate rates of change and patterns of convergence and divergence of chemical phenotypes.

This project will create outlets to educate the public about the ecology and evolution of insects, nocturnal life, and bioluminescence via a favorite insect. Moreover, drug discovery is a billion dollar business, and pharmaceutical chemists have long recognized that evolution has produced some of the most effective and profitable drugs ever. However, scientists still do not understand the mechanisms behind the origin and maintenance of chemical diversity. Insight into this question will help guide the next generation of pharmaceutical chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Complex traits - those consisting of multiple parts functioning as a single unit - are difficult to measure and compare among organisms. This research set out to quantify the diversity of chemical defenses across firefly species and, in particular, compare species with different levels of risk from predators (nocturnal species that flash, and diurnal species that do not).

First we needed to address the fundamental problem of how to measure and summarize complex chemical traits so that we could make meaningful comparisons. This challenge is not unique to our study system, and our methodological advances have carryover to fields ranging from gene expression to vegetation analysis. We established that a number of questions about complexity can be reframed as questions about diversity. Several recent advances in the mathematical analysis diversity can then be used to summarize complex traits with a relatively small number of parameters describing individual complexity, between-individual differences, and differences (or similarity) among populations, species, or other groups. We addressed the conceptual basis and implementation of this framework for analyzing diversity and complexity in a series of peer-reviewed papers and an R package.

Marion, Z.H., J.A. Fordyce, & B.M. Fitzpatrick. In Press. A hierarchical Bayesian model to partition diversity while accounting for incomplete sampling. Ecology.

Marion, Z.H., J.A. Fordyce, & B.M. Fitzpatrick. 2017. Pairwise beta diversity resolves an underappreciated source of confusion in diversity partitioning. Ecology 98: 933-939.

Marion Z.H., J.A. Fordyce, & B.M. Fitzpatrick. 2015. hierDiversity: Hierarchical Multiplicative Partitioning of Complex Phenotypes. R package version 0.1.

Marion ZH, Fordyce JA, Fitzpatrick BM. 2015. Extending the concept of diversity partitioning to characterize phenotypic complexity. American Naturalist 186: 348-361.

 

To compare flashing and non-flashing firefly species, we used liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) to chemically analyze hundreds of fireflies. We found that fireflies deter predators with a diverse, toxic cocktail of over 850 compounds. Much of the variation in toxin profiles can be explained by species identity and mate-signaling strategy. In particular, the chemotypes of nocturnal, bioluminescent fireflies are quite different from the toxins of day-active fireflies that signal mates with pheromones instead of light.

Moreover, one genus of fireflies, does not make toxins themselves. Called femmes fatales, female Photuris fireflies mimic the flashes of other species to attract males. When suitors approach in hopes of mating, they are eaten and their chemical defenses are stolen - sequestered and used by the predator for its own defense.

Using the methods described above, we learned that the average femme fatale possesses fewer compounds relative to other fireflies, but are quite different from one another, most likely due to random sampling of their prey.

Manuscripts detailing these results are currently in preparation.

Broader Impact

This project supported outlets to educate the public about the ecology and evolution of insects, nocturnal life, and bioluminescence via a favorite insect. This included numerous presentations to the public, including a repeated feature in The Great Smoky Mountains Spring Wildflower Pilgrimage. Or work and participation in firefly natural history also contributed to a wonderful book by our friend Lynn Faust ("Fireflies, Glow-worms, and lightning bugs" University of Georgia Press, 2017). Finally, drug discovery is a billion dollar business, and pharmaceutical chemists have long recognized that evolution has produced some of the most effective and profitable drugs ever. However, scientists still do not understand the mechanisms behind the origin and maintenance of chemical diversity. Insight into this question will help guide the next generation of pharmaceutical chemistry, including ongoing work in the University of Tennessee Department of Chemistry.
